channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Hackers Hide Cyberattacks in Social Media Posts
item.media:description: Jay Kaplan, left, and Mark Kuhr, the founders of Synack, a cybersecurity company. “The problem is pervasive,” Mr. Kaplan said.
item.description: A recent attack on the accounts of Defense Department employees suggests how easily people can be duped into clicking on dangerous links.
item.dc:creator: SHEERA FRENKEL
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: The Future of European Transit: Driverless and Utilitarian
item.media:description: A self-driving bus being tested in Helsinki. In Europe, driverless projects are focused on utilitarian self-driving vehicles for mass transit that barely exceed walking pace.
item.media:credit: Ugri Touko Tapani Hujanen for The New York Times
item.description: Across Europe, some fledgling driverless projects are focused on utilitarian self-driving vehicles for mass transit that barely exceed walking pace.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT

item.title: Is China Outsmarting America in A.I.?
item.media:description: Sören Schwertfeger at ShanghaiTech University, where a sizable grant has allowed him to set up an artificial intelligence lab.
item.media:credit: Tim Franco for The New York Times
item.description: Its ambitions mingle sci-fi ideas and big money with the needs of an authoritarian state.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR and JOHN MARKOFF
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Mother of Uber Chief Executive Killed in Boating Accident
item.media:description: Travis Kalanick, chief executive of Uber, in May 2016.
item.description: Travis Kalanick’s father was also seriously injured in the accident on Friday near Fresno, Calif., the company said.
item.dc:creator: MIKE ISAAC and BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: Tech Tip: When You See Something (Fake), Say Something
item.description: In its efforts to help curb the spread of false news around the world, Facebook has added new tools for users to aid in monitoring the site.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: The Week Ahead: A Monday Holiday Around the World, and May Hiring Data Is Due
item.media:description: Sales of new cars declined in the first four months of 2017.
item.description: Many financial markets will close for national holidays. As for jobs, Wall Street analysts expect that 176,000 people joined the work force.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: In China, Umbrellas and Basketballs Join the Sharing Economy
item.media:description: A Mobike ride-share lot in Beijing. The popularity of bike shares and other sharing ventures has prompted more innovative businesses, like a basketball-sharing one. Some question their viability.
item.description: Buoyed by the success of car- and bike-sharing companies and fueled with cash, Chinese start-ups are entering what some see as a sharing bubble.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: Bits: Farhad’s and Sheera’s Week in Tech: The Dark, Terrifying World of Hackers
item.media:description: Waymo’s self-driving minivan. Cybersecurity researchers are concerned about the risks posed by self-driving cars.
item.media:credit: Brett Carlsen for The New York Times
item.description: The Times’s new cybersecurity reporter explains why the prospect of self-driving cars strikes fear in the hearts of security reearchers.
item.dc:creator: FARHAD MANJOO and SHEERA FRENKEL

item.title: The Rise and Fall of Yik Yak, the Anonymous Messaging App
item.description: The app, which shut down in April, was plagued by bad press from the beginning, earning itself a reputation as a place for racism, sexism, bullying and bomb threats.
item.dc:creator: VALERIYA SAFRONOVA

item.title: Bits: Daily Report: Lessons From a Journey Through America
item.media:description: Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook, third from left, sitting down with the Gant family at their farm in Blanchardville, Wis.
item.description: Mark Zuckerberg is only about halfway through his goal to visit all the states, but the trips seem to be influencing his thinking, and his philosophy.
item.dc:creator: PUI-WING TAM

item.title: Tech Tip: Finding Missing Notifications
item.description: The iPhone and other mobile devices can alert you to breaking news and other events, as long as the settings are correct.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Waiting for the Credits to End? Movies Are Naming More Names
item.media:description: Some of the credits from the film “Star Trek Into Darkness” (2013).
item.description: Complex special effects can mean several thousand crew members are listed at the end. But not all workers are there, and some wish the scrolls were even longer.
item.dc:creator: MEKADO MURPHY

item.title: New Emoji is a Meaningful Symbol for Indigenous Australians
item.media:description: An Aboriginal flag near the Australian War Memorial in Canberra, Australia.
item.description: Twitter’s addition of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander flags comes in time for the 50th anniversary of a vote to include the communities in the national census.
item.dc:creator: TACEY RYCHTER

item.title: Modern Love: Wanting Monogamy as 1,946 Men Await My Swipe
item.description: They met on Bumble and fell into a fun, one-night-a-week, nonexclusive routine — until she realized she liked him.
item.dc:creator: LAUREN PETERSEN

item.title: Mark Zuckerberg’s Great American Road Trip
item.media:description: Mark Zuckerberg visited the Gant family on their farm in Blanchardville, Wis., in April.
item.description: The Facebook chief plans to visit every state in the union and learn more about a sliver of the nearly two billion people who use the social network regularly.
item.dc:creator: MIKE ISAAC

item.title: Dani Mathers, Former Playboy Model, Gets Community Service for Snapchat of Woman in Gym
item.media:description: Dani Mathers, center, at a hearing at Clara Shortridge Foltz Criminal Justice Center in Los Angeles on Wednesday.
item.description: Ms. Mathers must remove graffiti in Los Angeles after taking a photograph of a naked 70-year-old in a shower area, in a case seen as body shaming.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: Bits: Daily Report: AlphaGo Wins Again
item.media:description: Ke Jie lost the first two matches of a three-match series against the Google artificial intelligence program AlphaGo.
item.description: In the second match of a three-game series on Thursday, the computer program beat the 19-year-old Chinese prodigy Ke Jie in the strategy board game Go.
item.dc:creator: PUI-WING TAM

item.title: Tech Tip: Erasing Your Android Tracks
item.description: Google keeps a record of your searches and other activity across its sites, but you can delete the information, even with your phone or tablet.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Wheels: What Self-Driving Cars See
item.media:description: Raw data captured from a Luminar sensor while driving along San Francisco’s Embarcadero.
item.description: Lidar, the sensing technology, is the centerpiece of an intense court fight in California between two key players on the road, Uber and Waymo.
item.dc:creator: JOHN R. QUAIN

item.title: Google’s A.I. Program Rattles Chinese Go Master as It Wins Match
item.media:description: The Chinese Go master Ke Jie during his second game against AlphaGo, an artificial intelligence program, in Wuzhen, near Shanghai, on Thursday.
item.description: A Google program called AlphaGo won a best-of-three match against a Chinese Go master, rattling his nerves and showing the power of new artificial intelligence technologies.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR

item.title: Jacque Fresco, Futurist Who Envisioned a Society Without Money, Dies at 101
item.media:description: Jacque Fresco and a model of the Venus Project, which he began on 21 acres in Florida in 1980.
item.description: A self-taught industrial designer, Mr. Fresco promoted an alternative society where resources would be distributed equitably by computers.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD SANDOMIR

item.title: Bits: Daily Report: From Lean to Fat Start-Ups
item.media:description: Eric Wu, a founder and the chief executive of Opendoor, at the company’s headquarters in San Francisco.
item.media:credit: Christie Hemm Klok for The New York Times
item.description: Silicon Valley, which once favored enterprises that didn’t require much capital, is flush with cash, and entrepreneurs are tackling big — some would say crazy — ideas.
item.dc:creator: PUI-WING TAM

item.title: Mediator: Sean Hannity, a Murder and Why Fake News Endures
item.media:description: FoxNews.com and the Fox affiliate in Washington, WTTG, quoted an investigator working with the Rich family as saying that Seth Rich had been in contact with WikiLeaks before his death.
item.description: As the case of the Seth Rich murder shows, uncorroborated stories will spread as long as some people want to tell them, and others want to believe.
item.dc:creator: JIM RUTENBERG

item.title: Tech Tip: In Search of the Simple Sign-In
item.description: A tool in Apple’s iOS 10 software can save you a lot of password typing to stream video, but it doesn’t work with every TV provider or app.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Tech Fix: Reality Check: What Does, and Doesn’t, Protect Your Smartphone
item.description: Why you should buy a case for your smartphone, and maybe a screen protector, but pass on an extended warranty.
item.dc:creator: BRIAN X. CHEN

item.title: Tech We're Using: With a Bazaar of Gizmos and Apps, Tackling Readers’ Tech Questions
item.media:description: J.D. Biersdorfer at her desk with some of the devices she uses.
item.description: The New York Times’s Tech Tips columnist describes the arsenal of gadgets at her disposal, and her special love for iPhone.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Brazilian Uber Rival Raises $100 Million From SoftBank
item.media:description: The founder of SoftBank, Masayoshi Son, above, met with the chief executive of 99, Peter Fernandez, in Tokyo last week.
item.description: The investment in the start-up 99 comes despite recent political turmoil in Brazil.
item.dc:creator: VINOD SREEHARSHA

item.title: State of the Art: The Rise of the Fat Start-Up
item.description: A service called Opendoor, which will make an offer on your house sight unseen, illustrates a new breed of start-up and Silicon Valley’s ever-widening ambitions.
item.dc:creator: FARHAD MANJOO

item.title: Unity Technologies, Whose Engine Is Behind Pokémon Go, Agrees to Funding
item.media:description: Japanese students played “Pokemon Go” in Tokyo in July.
item.description: If a new investment round closes, it could bring Unity, which makes software at the heart of video games, $400 million and value it at about $2.6 billion.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

item.title: Market Value: Angry Over Zillow’s Home Prices? You Can Win a Prize by Improving Them
item.media:description: A new house for sale in Chicago. Zillow’s home estimates have been pilloried for inaccuracy, though they’ve grown better over time.
item.description: The overall accuracy of Zillow’s estimates has gotten better, and it’s now announcing a $1 million award to sharpen the company’s algorithm further.
item.dc:creator: NICK WINGFIELD

item.title: Uber to Repay Millions to Drivers, Who Could Be Owed Far More
item.media:description: An Uber driver in the Bronx. A lawsuit last year said that Uber was committing a form of wage theft.
item.media:credit: Mark Kauzlarich for The New York Times
item.description: The company concedes taking tens of millions in excess commissions. But records point to improper tax deductions costing drivers even more.
item.dc:creator: NOAM SCHEIBER

item.title: Federal Court Revives Wikimedia’s Challenge to N.S.A. Surveillance
item.media:description: The director of the National Security Agency, Adm. Michael S. Rogers, in Washington on Tuesday. A court ruled that Wikimedia has grounds to sue the N.S.A. over Fourth Amendment privacy rights.
item.description: An appeals court ruling on warrantless internet surveillance raises the chances that the Supreme Court could one day scrutinize the issue.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Target to Pay $18.5 Million to 47 States in Security Breach Settlement
item.media:description: Target’s headquarters in Minneapolis. A settlement by the company ended an investigation into how the data of millions of customers was compromised in 2013.
item.media:credit: Glen Stubbe/Star Tribune, via Associated Press
item.description: The agreement, which includes the District of Columbia, ends an investigation into how hackers obtained information about tens of millions of people in 2013.
item.dc:creator: RACHEL ABRAMS

item.title: Bits: Daily Report: AlphaGo Shows How Far Artificial Intelligence Has Come
item.media:description: The Google artificial intelligence program AlphaGo beat the top-ranked Chinese Go player, Ke Jie, in Wuzhen, China, in the first game of a three-game match.
item.description: The computer program DeepMind’s AlphaGo has defeated the top-ranked Chinese Go player, Ke Jie, in the first match of a three-game series.
item.dc:creator: PUI-WING TAM

item.title: Tech Tip: Doing a 180 on Facebook 360 Photos
item.description: Facebook converts many wide-angle panorama photos to 360-degree interactive images when they are uploaded, but you can revert to the original.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Apple Settles Legal Dispute With Nokia
item.media:description: A Nokia logo in Zenica, Bosnia, in 2014. The Finnish company used to be the world’s largest seller of mobile phones.
item.description: The iPhone maker has agreed to a new licensing deal with the Finnish telecommunications company, ending a six-month battle over technology patents.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT

item.title: Need Mood Lighting to Go With Your Music? Ask Alexa. No App Required.
item.media:description: Ikea has made a deal with Amazon for its voice-enabled products, allowing Ikea’s new line of smart light bulbs to be controlled by Amazon’s Echo speaker.
item.description: The e-commerce giant Amazon plans to connect its voice-command Echo technology to Ikea’s new line of smart lighting products.
item.dc:creator: NICK WINGFIELD

item.title: More Evidence Points to North Korea in Ransomware Attack
item.media:description: Eric Chien of Symantec, front, said that technical evidence indicated that a group of North Korean hackers that experts call the Lazarus Group was behind the WannaCry attack.
item.media:credit: Michal Czerwonka for The New York Times
item.description: Researchers at the security company Symantec have found more digital clues that offer hints to who was responsible for the global incident.
item.dc:creator: NICOLE PERLROTH
